testMsg: Answer 10 questions. Correctly answer atleast 6 questions to pass the test.
earnMsg: Watch sponsored content to earn +3 credits?

questions.questionText: Name two promises that new citizens make in the Oath of Allegiance?
options: Give up loyalty to other countries and defend the (U.S.) Constitution
Be free to express yourself and not cause trouble
Serve in the military and bear arms
To petition the government if it does anything wrong and be employed in the United States

questions.questionText: Who can vote in federal elections, run for federal office, and serve on a jury in the United States?
options: Permanent Residence of the United States
Anyone in the United States during time of election

questions.questionText: How can people become United States citizens?
options: Be born in the United States

questions.questionText: What do we show loyalty to when we say the Pledge of Allegiance?
Which of the following is a right only for U.S. Citizens?
options: Vote in a federal election and serve on a jury
Serve on a jury and free access to healthcare
Run for federal office and serve on a jury.
Vote in a federal election and run for federal office.

questions.questionText: It is important for all men age 18 through 25 to register for the Selective Service. Name one reason why?
options: Makes the draft fair, if needed.

questions.questionText: When must all men register for the Selective Service?
options: All male between the age of 16 & 21 must register within 30 days of arriving to the US and within 30 days of their 18th birthday.
All male between the age of 18 & 21 must register within 30 days of arriving to the US and within 30 days of their 18th birthday.
All male between the age of 16 & 25 must register within 30 days of arriving to the US and within 30 days of their 18th birthday.
All male between the age of 18 & 25 must register within 30 days of arriving to the US and within 30 days of their 18th birthday.

questions.questionText: What are two examples of civic participation in the United States?
options: Join a political party and join a civic group
Get a driver's license and attend school

questions.questionText: What are the four amendments to the Constitution about who can vote?
options: Citizens twenty one (21) and older (can vote). You don't have to pay (a poll tax) to vote. Any citizen can vote. (Women and men can vote.) A male citizen of any race (can vote).
Citizens sixteen(16) and older (can vote). You don't have to pay (a poll tax) to vote. Any citizen can vote. (Women and men can vote.) A male citizen of any race (can vote).
Citizens eighteen (18) and older (can vote). You don't have to pay (a poll tax) to vote. Any citizen and immigrant can vote. (Women and men can vote.) A male citizen of any race (can vote).
Citizens eighteen (18) and older (can vote). You don't have to pay (a poll tax) to vote. Any citizen can vote. (Women and men can vote.) A male citizen of any race (can vote).

questions.questionText: What is the responsibility that is only for U.S. Citizens?
Why is it important to pay federal taxes?
options: It's required by law (16th Amendment) and to fund the federal government
Federal tax is optional and not mandatory
To support the president of the United States

questions.questionText: What is one way Americans can serve their country?
What are three rights of everyone living in the United States?
options: Freedom of speech, freedom of religion and freedom of expression
Freedom of religion, freedom of expression and freedom to make treaties with other countries
Freedom of speech, freedom of expression and freedom to run for president
Freedom to petition the government, freedom of expression and freedom to disobey traffic laws

questions.questionText: What U.S. war ended slavery?
Name one leader of the women's rights movement in the 1800s.?
Name one war fought by the United States in the 1800s.?
When did all men get the right to vote?
What amendment gives citizenship to all persons born in the United States?
Name the U.S. War between the North and the South.?
What did the Emancipation Proclamation do?
options: Gave women the right to vote
Freed slaves in most Southern states
Gave the United States independence from Great Britain

questions.questionText: The Civil War had many important events. Name one.?
What was one important thing that Abraham Lincoln did?
What territory did the U.S. Buy from France in 1803?
What is Independence Day.?
options: A: A holiday to celebrate U.S. independence (from Britain)
B: The day when the South seceded from the Union

questions.questionText: Name two national U.S. holidays.?
options: April Fool's Day and Labor Day

questions.questionText: What is Veterans Day?
options: A holiday to honor soldiers who died in military service
A holiday to honor the victims of 9/11
A holiday that recognizes everyone who served in the Armed Forces
A holiday to honor the people who died fighting for civil rights

questions.questionText: When do we celebrate Independence Day?
What is Memorial Day?
options: A holiday to honor soldiers who died in military service
A holiday to honor the victims of 9/11
A holiday that recognizes everyone who served in the Armed Forces
A holiday to honor the people who died fighting for civil rights

questions.questionText: Why did the United States enter the Korean War?
Dwight Eisenhower is famous for many things. Name one.?
options: Developed nuclear bombs that were dropped into Japan during World War II
Pulled the United States from the Great Depression

questions.questionText: When did all women get the right to vote?
Name one American Indian tribe in the United States?
Name one U.S. military conflict after the September 11, 2001 attacks?
What is the name of the national anthem?
Who was the United States' main rival during the Cold War?
Why did the United States enter the Persion Gulf War?
options: to force the Iraqi military from Kuwait
stop the spread of Iran's influence

questions.questionText: When did the Great Depression Start?
Name one war fought by the United States in the 1900s.?
What was the Great Depression?
options: Period of low morale in the country during WWII
A nickname for the Grand Canyon
Longest economic recession in modern history
A long period of time where the United States had the lowest literacy rates

questions.questionText: Who was the President during World War II and the Great Depression?
What happened on September 11, 2001 in the United States?
Name one example of an American innovation?
What movement tried to end racial discrimination?
What was the main concern of the United States during the Cold War?
Why did the United States enter the Vietnam War?
What did the civil rights movement do?
options: Gave women the right to vote
Gave minorities the right to vote

questions.questionText: Why did the United States enter World War I?
options: 2: To support the Allied Powers (England, France, Italy, and Russia) and oppose the central powers
3: In retaliation on the attack on Pearl Harbor

questions.questionText: What did Martin Luther King, Jr. do?
options: Ran for the president of the United States

questions.questionText: Why did the United States enter World War II?
options: To get out of the Great Depression
Give the military something to do

questions.questionText: What is the form of government of the United States?
options: Republic, Constitution-based federal republic and Representative democracy
Socialism, Constitution-based federal republic and Representative democracy
Republic, Constitution-based federal republic and Monarchy
Republic, an oligarchy and Representative democracy

questions.questionText: How many amendments does the U.S. Constitution have?
Name one thing the U.S. Constitution does?
What founding document said the American colonies were free from Britain?
What is the economic system of the United States?
What does Bill of Rights protect?
The U.S. Constitution starts with the words "We the People". What does "We the People" mean?
The words "Life, Liberty and the pursuit of Happiness" are in what founding document?
Name two important ideas from the Declaration of Independence and the U.S. Constitution?
What is the supreme law of the land?
options: UN Charter of Rights and Freedoms

questions.questionText: The "Rule of law" is:
options: Everyone must follow the law. Leaders obey some laws but not all. Government must obey the law. No one is above the law.
Everyone must follow the law. Leaders must obey the law. Government is exempt from some laws. No one is above the law
Everyone must follow the law. Leaders must obey the law. Government must obey the law. The president is above the law
Everyone must follow the law. Leaders must obey the law. Government must obey the law. No one is above the law.

questions.questionText: Why is the Declaration of Independence important?
options: A: It says America is free from British Control
C: It established another country up north

questions.questionText: How many amendments does the U.S. Constitution have?
There are three branches of government. Why?
How are changes made to the U.S. Constitution?
Many documents influenced the U.S. Constitution. Name two?
options: Declaration of Independence and UN Charter of Human Rights
Articles of Federation and Fundamental Orders of New York
Articles of Confederation and Federalist Papers
Anti-Federalist Papers and Virginia Law of Peace

questions.questionText: When was the Constitution written?
Who wrote the Declaration of Independence?
There were ____ original states?
There were 13 original states. Name 5.
options: New York, Kentucky, California, Virginia and Georgia
Virginia, North Carolina, California, New York and Florida
Washington, Oregon, New York, Florida and California
Maryland, Virginia, New York, Delaware and North Carolina

questions.questionText: What group of people was taken and sold as slaves?
Thomas Jefferson is famous for many things. Name one.?
options: Writer of the Declaration of Independence
First president of the United States

questions.questionText: The colonists fought the British because:
options: Of high taxes, no freedom of speech and they didn't have self-government
Of poor infrastructure, the British army stayed in their houses and they didn't have self-government
Of high taxes, the British army stayed in their houses and they didn't have healthcare
Of high taxes, the British army stayed in their houses and they didn't have their own self-government

questions.questionText: The American Revolution had many important events. Name two?
options: Battle of Bunker Hill and Battle of Gettysburg
Declaration of Independence and Washington Crossing the Delaware (Battle of Trenton)
Battle of Yorktown and the Burning of the White House
Declaration of Independence and the Freeing of Slaves

questions.questionText: When was the Declaration of Independence adopted?
What Founding document was written in 1787?
Who lived in America before the Europeans arrived?
Who was the first President?
What war did the Americans fight to win independence from Britain?
Alexander Hamilton is famous for many things. Name one.
options: Fourth president of the United States

questions.questionText: James Madison is famous for many things. Name one
options: Third president of the United States
Doubled the size of the United States
Writer of the Declaration of Independence

questions.questionText: George Washington is famous for many things. Name one:?
options: First president of the United States
One of the writers of the Federalist Papers
Helped establish the First Bank of the United States

questions.questionText: The Federalist Papers supported the passage of the U.S. Constitution. Name one of the writers.
The Federalist Papers supported the passage of the U.S. Constitution. Name one of the writers.
What is one thing Benjamin Franklin is famous for?
options: The youngest member of the Constitutional Convention
Third president of the United States

questions.questionText: Why were the Federalist Papers important?
options: It was the detailed version of the US Constitution
It rallied people to support the revolution
They helped people understand and supported the passing of the (U.S.) Constitution.

questions.questionText: Why did colonists come to America?
options: For freedom, for economic opportunity and for education
For freedom, for economic opportunity and for better healthcare
For freedom, for education and to escape persecution
For freedom, for economic opportunity and to escape persecution

questions.questionText: Why does the flag have 13 stripes?
options: Because the stripes represent the original colonies
Because it was considered lucky to have 13 stripes on a flag
Because the stripes represent the number of signatures on the U.S. Constitution
Because the stripes represent the members of the Second Continental Congress

questions.questionText: Why does the flag have 50 stars?
options: Because there is one star for each president
Because there is one star for each state
Because there were 50 people who originally came to the United States

questions.questionText: Where is the Statue of Liberty?
What is the capital of the United States?
The Nation's first motto was "E Pluribus Unum." What does that mean?
Supreme Court justices serve for life. Why?
options: to increase their influence on the president

questions.questionText: How many senators does each state have?
How long do Supreme Court justices serve?
Why do U.S. representatives serve shorter terms than U.S. senators?
options: The president wants more frequent turnover of the representatives
It aligns with the state elections
To more closely follow public opinion

questions.questionText: How many years is a U.S. Senator elected for?
Who elects members of the House of Representatives?
Name the powers of the U.S. Congress.
options: Writes laws, Declares war and makes the federal budget.
Writes laws, select cabinet members and makes the federal budget
Selects the supreme court judges, writes laws and makes federal budget
Writes laws, selects the supreme court judges and declares war

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of the 10th Amendment?
options: Powers not given to the federal government belong to the states or to the people
Limits the president to two terms

questions.questionText: What are two Cabinet-level positions?
options: Secretary of Health and Human Services and Secretary of the Navy
Secretary of Weather and Secretary of Energy
Secretary of the Interior and Secretary of History
Secretary of State and Secretary of Labor

questions.questionText: The House of Representatives has how many voting members?
How many justices are on the Supreme Court?
Name one part of the executive branch?
The President of the United States is in charge of which branch of government?
How many Supreme Court justices are usually needed to decide a case?
What is the highest court in the United States?
Under our Constitution, some powers belong to the federal government. What is one power of the federal government?
What are the two parts of the U.S. Congress?
options: The Senate and House of Representatives
The courts and House of Representatives

questions.questionText: How many years is a U.S. Representative elected for?
Who is the Commander in Chief of the military?
Under our Constitution, which of the following is NOT a power of the states?
options: To approve zoning and land use
